text: hi guys I'm Laura Vitale on this episode
of Laura in the kitchen I'm going to
show you how to make a breakfast
bruschetta it is so yummy easy and
simple so yes let's go over the
ingredients so we can get started you're
going to need some thinly sliced
pancetta you're going to need some eggs
some fresh chopped parsley garlic thyme
some bread some parmigiano unsalted
butter olive oil and salt and pepper
okay let's get right into it get your
oven preheated to 425 and lay a baking
sheet with some aluminum foil this is
just so that nothing sticks and now on
here I'm going to put my punch it down
and this is going to get nice and crispy
if you can't find fun Chetta which is
really the Italian version of bacon you
can always use regular bacon but it's it
this is just not smoked and it gives you
more of a salty with prosciutto like
taste instead of a smoky taste but bacon
works
put a little more bacon I love bacon put
this back here and let's put together
first I'm going to do is I'm going to
lay my bread down just like so and in
this little tiny bowl I'm going to mix
together my parsley garlic and thyme mix
it all up
get it combined and now on my bread I'm
just going to drizzle it with a little
bit of oil and I'm going to sprinkle
this mixture all over the top and as it
bakes it's going to get super fragrant
and it's going to be fabulous especially
when we top it with an egg it's yummy
and then we're going to sprinkle a
little bit of cheese on the top of that
like that not too too much but just
enough and now I'm going to put this
into the oven and this is only going to
take about 10 to 15 minutes until the
puncher is nice and crispy and
the breads nice and toasted so it goes
while my bread and pancetta are still in
the oven for a few minutes we're going
to make the eggs and in this skillet I
have a little bit of olive oil and a
little bit of butter because I like the
flavor of butter the olive oil has a
higher cooking temperature it doesn't
burn as fast as butter does so and that
over medium heat and I'm going to wait
for that to get nice and hot and the
butter melt now for the eggs
I always Craig eggs I crack them in a
separate Bowl like in a small bowl that
way when I put them into the pan they
kind of stay in their shape and they
don't kind of run all over the place so
well that's one that gets hot I'm going
to add my eggs one at a time and then
I'll show you how i season them and how
I like to cook them a lot of time just
add your egg it shouldn't be too hot
because eggs are a protein and this
should cook somewhat slowly
that way they don't get too sort of
tough and rubbery eggs are almost done
just going to season them with some salt
and pepper and I'm going to turn them
off now if you want your eggs like your
egg yolks cooked all the way then by all
means do that but I like them nice and
runny so I cook them on one side for
about three three-and-a-half minutes my
bread and pancetta came out of the oven
put them on a platter and then I top
each one pancetta which is really nice
and crispy now but it's not too crispy
and that it's going to be difficult to
eat last one and then whoops you top
each one with an egg now that they're
all assembled I'm going to put one on my
plates and I cut into it oh yeah oh I
love the runny yolk is a bite
that's Oh God
doesn't get any better than that for a
weekend breakfast that's easy and
delicious throw www long mission
accomplished recipe now see you next
time
